Scenario 2

Capt P was transporting 15kg of .22 ammunition in a wooden box placed in the bed of his pick-up truck. He was driving along a highway when he hit an un-marked large bump. The tailgate of his truck popped open and the box of ammunition was thrown from the truck bed. It rolled across the road, barely missing another vehicle. The ammunition box was damaged and rounds were scattered through the ditch.

 

Was Capt P negligent?

Capt P could be found negligent in that he didn’t take reasonable precautions to secure the ammunition in his truck. The standard that Capt P would be held to is greater than that of an ordinary person – Capt P has been trained and should have known to secure the ammunition so that it could not become dislodged while driving or in an accident.

 

Section 86 (1) of the Criminal Code: Every person commits an offence who, without lawful excuse, uses, carries, handles, ships, transports or stores …any ammunition … in a careless manner or without reasonable precautions for the safety of other persons.

 

In addition, if the box of ammunition had hit someone, they could have been very badly injured   and Capt P would have been liable.
